awd_titl_txt: i-REU: The US/France Exchange Program in Chemistry: Forming Global Scientists for the 21st Century
awd_abstract_narration:
Professors Valeria Kleiman, Adrian Roitberg, and colleagues at the University of Florida host the United States/France exchange for undergraduate research experiences in chemistry. This site is cofunded by the REU Sites Program of the Division of Chemistry and the Office of International Science and Engineering. The site promotes the progress of science supporting the international education of undergraduate students from the US. The emphasis of the exchange is to provide each student with a meaningful international summer research project in Chemistry in French laboratories. Internationalization of science is an imperative in order to create a diverse and culturally-aware STEM work-force. Those participating in international science benefit from increased visibility, funding and career advances and those participating in a global research environment learn to think outside the box. In addition, these are life-changing experiences where students become global citizens and learn to interact with scientists with different backgrounds who teach and mentor them in chemistry. To complement the research environment, the intellectual value of the program is enhanced by the cohort activities where students learn to disseminate their discoveries and become global scientists. This program acts as a true exchange, where students from France also come to the US to perform research during the time of the program. 

Participants are assigned in groups of two or more at each of the three French sites (Paris, Toulouse and Strasbourg). They are matched with available host groups according to their previous experience. Research topics cover broad areas of the chemistry field and include the bottom up structuring and patterning of materials; the design, synthesis, and characterization of supramolecular systems; the characterization of inorganic, organic, and biological solid materials; studies of the anti-inflammatory effects of N-acyl-homoserine lactones on epithelial cells; the controlled synthesis of complex nanoparticles; and the preparation of molecules with potential applications in homogeneous or heterogeneous catalysis.

por.por_cntn:
The Univ of Florida international-REU program provided early exposure to international research laboratories for a diverse group of undergraduate students with the goal of encouraging them to pursue graduate programs in chemistry and/or chemistry related fields.

Our holistic recruitment approach helped in targeting students that might have been overlooked under more traditional methods of selection.  As we selected the different cohorts of students, we always kept in mind that this International REU aims to attract non-traditional students into STEM fields and to provide an experience that will encourage them to pursue graduate education. 

Most of our recruited students came from non-research-intensive institutions. These students were able, through careful mentoring, that they were indeed ready for the challenges of an international experience and advanced research.

CHE-1659782 has been quite productive, with the i-REU site operating each summer from 2017 through 2022, with an interruption in ?20 and a small cohort in ?21 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.  

The exchange promoted the progress of science supporting the international education of undergraduate students from everywhere in the US with 12 weeks of research experience in exceptional chemistry laboratories in France. A strong partnership between the Univ. of Florida and 3 French institutions (Sorbonne Universit?, Strasbourg Universit?, and Universit? P. Sabatier) resulted in the exchange of 86 students (40 US students  performing research during 12 weeks in France while  46 French students performed research for 12-15 weeks  at the University of Florida.   

The main outcome of the REU program has always been for the students to be able to have an experience that allowed them to be listed as co-authors on a publication or a poster. Every US participant presented a poster at a National ACS Spring meeting, in divisions such as PMSE, PHYS, CHEM, ORG and CHED.

So far, 15 publications have resulted from this funding period, but as expected, there is a substantial time-lag between the work and the actual publication, so we expect many more to be published eventually.

An important goal of REU programs is to continue student training in the sciences; an equally important goal is fostering interest in the pursuit of science degrees and career pathways. Overall, 90% of the students are attending or plan to attend graduate school in STEM areas (most in chemistry, but also in biomedical engineering, material science, experimental and molecular medicine).   Of those surveyed, 13 had applied for NSF Graduate fellowships and 4 obtained it.  These outstanding students have a common attribute: they all appreciate the opportunity provided by the i-REU program and acknowledge NSF for helping them become more competitive when applying for fellowships and acceptance in prestigious graduate schools.  Some of that appreciation can be read in the following remarks by a participant:

"It inspired me to pursue graduate studies. Working in a lab in France reassured my interest in analytical chemistry and provided me with the necessary skills and experience to apply for graduate studies." And "It also opened up many opportunities for me. I disseminated my poster from this REU at different conferences. Through these conferences, I met and networked with fellow students and scientists. Best of all I learned about my current graduate school."
